title-group.article-title: Criteria for the use of modular networks: fatigue in composite materials

article-meta.aff: 1Programa de Pós-Graduação em Engenharia Mecânica-UFRN, Campus Universitário, Natal, Brazil
2Departamento de Engenharia Mecânica (UFRN), Campus Universitário, Natal, Brazil

author-notes.corresp: Raimundo Carlos Silverio Freire Júnior, Universidade Federal do Rio Grande do Norte (UFRN), Campus Universitário, Natal, Brazil Email: freirej@ufrnet.br

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2012 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: This study examines the influence of dataset choice on neural network training, comparing the dataset using the S–N curves most commonly obtained in the literature (R = 10, −1, and 0.1) with two others that exchange alternate S–N curve (R = −1) data for another S–N curve, which can be chosen either within the variable load region with predominance of tension or the variable load region with predominance of compression. In addition, the present investigation defines a stopping criterion for modular network training. A total of 10 datasets drawn from the literature were analyzed to achieve the desired results.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Previous knowledge of fatigue behavior for a material is of great importance in any structural design subjected to cyclic loading. Therefore, a mathematical model that clearly and accurately defines this behavior is highly desirable. Initially, static and dynamic tests are performed to analyze the fatigue behavior of materials. Based on these results, the S–N curves (stress amplitude versus number of cycles) and equations applied to model S–N curve behavior are then used to construct constant-life fatigue diagrams (CLDs), which are essential to the study and applicability of these materials. However, these diagrams, when built with a small number of S–N curves, underestimate or overestimate the current behavior of the composite, thus demonstrating the ever-increasing need to perform more tests for more accurate results.1,2

Previous studies3,4 have conducted detailed investigations on a large number of mathematical equations depicting fatigue behavior of composite materials. Nevertheless, none of these are sufficiently broad to represent the fatigue behavior of any composite material. As such, the search for a mathematical model that demonstrates this type of behavior remains an open field of study.

In light of the aforementioned difficulties in fatigue life modeling, some authors4–10 began using artificial neural networks to model this type of behavior. In a pioneering study, Lee5 listed the reasons why the fatigue behavior of a composite material can be modeled with neural networks as follows: the existence of a database related to the material; there is no accurate solution for the problem, or none is known, but mathematical approaches exist; and experimental data obtained are incomplete, highly dispersive, and complex. As such, the fatigue behavior of composite materials has great potential for analysis using artificial neural networks.

Al-Assaf et al.6,7 subsequently published a study using a composite material in the form of a laminate (epoxy resin with glass fiber) as database, which was tested to fatigue in the direction of the fiber and in various other directions (19, 45, 71, and 90°). The following stress ratios were applied: R = −1, 0, and 0.5. Multilayer perceptron architecture was used, trained with the retro-programming algorithm, where authors tested several entries in the network, as well as different architectures. The present study has made significant contributions to the application of neural networks in the pretreatment of training data.

Prior research by Freire Jr.3,8,9 confirmed that well-formulated network architecture and the incorporation of prior knowledge produced good results. Furthermore, in the case of a modular network (MN), the use of three S–N curves satisfactorily modeled fatigue behavior.

However, these studies are still only presented as proof of the concept, without necessarily displaying an algorithm with well-defined criteria to establish which S–N curves to use in training and which stopping criterion to apply in each case.
But, which procedure should be used for an initial assessment when there is a small amount of data?

In attempting to answer this question, previous studies10,11 have shown that using three S–N curves produced reliable and robust results. However, there are still two points to be evaluated: which S–N curves should be used in training and which stopping criterion should be applied for completion of the algorithm?

Accordingly, the present study aims to analyze 10 different datasets, all drawn from the literature, in order to define criteria that can be used for the training and application of an MN in fatigue behavior analysis of composite materials.

sec.title: Materials obtained from the literature
sec.p: A total of nine materials drawn from the literature were used: HTA/913, IM7/977, T800/5245, and T800/3631 made from carbon fibers, and DD16, C10, C12, MAT(0)2, and QQ1 made from glass fibers. The last (QQ1) was analyzed in the principal direction of the fiber and transversally to it (QQ1t), totaling 10 evaluated datasets.

Laminates C10 and C12 were industrially manufactured using the manual lamination process (hand lay-up) with orthophthalic unsaturated polyester resin and E-glass fiber reinforcement in the form of mats (M; 5 cm, 450 g/m2) and bidirectional textile fabrics (T; 450 g/m2). These laminates have C10 (M/T/M/T/M) and C12 (M/T/M/T/M/M/T/M/T/M/T/M) configuration (stacking sequence).

The DD16 laminate is a glass fiber-reinforced plastic obtained from the literature.11 Its fiber volume is 36% and is fabricated with a resin transfer molding process, where the matrix is orthopolyester and configuration (90/0/±45/0)s. In the layers at 0° and 90°, it exhibits type D155 (527 g/m2) glass fiber fabric and at ±45°, type DB (393 g/m2) fabric.

Another material employed is MAT(0)2,11 a glass fiber-reinforced plastic with two layers, tested in the principal direction of the fiber and made in the form of D155 fabric with a weight of 527 g/m2. The polyester-based matrix, in which Coresina 63-AX-051 is used through the resin transfer molding process, has a glass fiber volume of 48%.

Additionally, we used data from four carbon fiber laminates: HTA/913, made from ENKA fiber and BLS-913 epoxy matrix; T800/5245, with Toray fiber and epoxy/Narmcobismaleimide matrix; IM7/977, with Hercules fiber and modified epoxy matrix 977; and T800/3631, with Toray fiber (T800H) and epoxy resin 3631 and configuration (45/90/−45/0)2s. The other laminates (HTA/913, T800/5245, and IM7/977) display a [(±45.02)2]s configuration with a fiber volume of 65% and are manufactured using the autoclave vacuum molding process.12
For a better understanding of the configurations and manufacturing process of previously mentioned materials, the following literature articles3,11–15 can be consulted.

sec.title: Data preprocessing
sec.p: In order to obtain the S–N curves of materials studied here, we applied the generalized ‘power law,’ depicted in Equation (1). This equation was selected over others used in the literature16–18 because it exhibits better coefficients of correlation with the experimental data analyzed. (1)log(σa)=A-B[log(N)]P

In the above equation, A, B, and P are constants that must be determined from the experimental data, N is the number of cycles until rupture of the material, and σa is the stress amplitude to which the material is subjected. The values of constants A, B, and P for each stress ratio given by Equation (1) are shown in Tables 1–3, where UTS is the ultimate tensile stress value and UCS is the ultimate compressive stress value, and r is the correlation coefficient. Values for constants shown in Tables 1–3 refer to materials HTA-913, IM7-977, T800-5245, T800/3631, QQ1, and QQ1t, while those representing the remaining materials can be found in previous studies.8,18 Table 1.
Data obtained for the S–N curves and stress ratios of materials HTA/913 and IM7/977
R HTA/913 R IM7/977 R
A B P A B P
10 2.62 0.026 1.20 0.97 2.57 0.0045 1.88 0.93
−1.5 2.87 0.0013 3 0.92 2.81 0.00067 3 0.90
−1 2.99 0.013 1.81 0.99 2.95 0.02 1.36 0.94
−0.3 2.91 0.00084 3 0.99 2.99 0.00089 3 0.79
0.1 2.74 0.00046 3 0.95 2.78 0.00037 3 0.90
UCS = −970(MPa) UTS = 1270 (MPa)
UCS = −900 (MPa) UTS = 1430 (MPa)

sec.title: Modular network
sec.p: For creation of the neural architecture, an MN with a hidden layer in each of its two modules was used, where each module consists of a multilayer perceptron network. The number of hidden neurons in each module varied between 5 and 25. All of these displayed bias, sigmoid activation function in the hidden layer and linear function in the output neuron and were trained by the back propagation algorithm to produce a function satisfying the condition shown in Equation (2): (2)σa=f(σmed,N) where σa is the applied stress amplitude (maximum stress minus minimum stress divided by two), σmed is the mean stress (maximum stress plus minimum stress divided by two), and N is the number of cycles in which rupture of the material occurs.

Overall, MNs have a ‘divide and conquer’ operating principle. This type of network creates specialists through different training for each module. By using a passage network, weights are applied to each module making them responsible, to a greater or lesser degree, for the overall outcome of the network. Figure 1 shows a diagram of how this process was used for fatigue behavior modeling of composite materials.10 Figure 1.
Diagram demonstrating modular network architecture.

The present study constructed a network with a specialized module on tensile fatigue behavior, and another on the compression fatigue behavior of the composite. This specialization was defined by dividing the training dataset into two subsets. As shown in Figure 2, TENS represents the training subset related to data with tensile loads and COMP represents the subset in which data have compressive loads. Data from the training set with variable cyclic loading (tension–compression) are applied in both the TENS and COMP subsets. Figure 2.
Flow diagram depicting neural network training of two modules.

Data normalization occurred in both the input and output neurons; in the case of average tension, this normalization occurred considering its signal, per Equations (3) and (4). This modification in normalization was carried out to produce better data distribution, thereby facilitating MN learning. (3)σmednor=σmedσult∴σult=UTS if σmed≥0 ∴σult =UCS if σmed≤0 (4)σanor=σaσamax∴σamax=σa*=UTS-UCS2

The decision criterion used when dividing the TENS and COMP subsets relied on the value of the normalized σmed. The TENS subset was obtained from training data with σmednor values higher than −0.4, while data exhibiting values lower than 0.4 make up the COMP subset.

Cross-validation is commonly used to assess neural network capacity in predicting the behavior of an ‘environment.’ A schematic diagram demonstrating use of this technique for materials employed here is shown in Figure 3. Cross-validation aims to train the MN with a set containing few S–N curves, while testing it for each training period with the entire dataset so as to select the best result is represented by the RMSMIN (minimum mean square error). Figure 3.
Algorithm used to analyze the datasets studied.

During the training process, both the behavior of the RMS (Equation (5)) for the training set and that of the total dataset were observed in order to assess artificial neural network (ANN) generalization. (5)RMS=12·Q·∑1Q∑i=1m(di-zi)2

In the above equation, RMS corresponds to the root mean square, Q represents the size of the dataset, m corresponds to the number of output neurons (in this paper m = 1), and di and zi reflect desired and actual responses of the output node, respectively. These values represent the network output, that is, normalized alternating stress (σanor).
However, two points remain to be evaluated: which S–N curves should be used in training and which stopping criterion should be applied to complete the algorithm?

Figure 4 presents a schematic diagram of the final application for the algorithm when there are only three S–N curves. Figure 4.
Application of the algorithm considering material with only three S–N curves.

Thus, the present study aimed to analyze the influence of dataset choice on neural network training. The dataset that considers the most evaluated S–N curves, for R = 10, −1, and 0.1, was compared with two other datasets where the curve is exchanged either for R = −1, or for an R within the variable load region with predominance of tension (T–C) or predominance of compression (C–T), in order to determine the data region that best represents the general behavior of the composite material. To better understand the load regions with respect to the R value, the layout of these regions delimited by the stress ratio (R) is shown in the stress amplitude (σa) versus average stress (σmed) graph displayed in Figure 5. Figure 5.
Graph of alternating stress (σa) versus mean stress (σmed) showing stress ratio variation.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: This study presents the results obtained for the MN. Learning capacity is known to depend on the representativeness of available samples and the complexity of network architecture. Moreover, excessive training can also lead to an unsatisfactory outcome and lack of a representative dataset to validate the network is common. Previous investigations9,10 have found the ideal solution would be to apply common sense, by limiting the training epocs and the RMSTRE value. Another significant factor is the choice of dataset. For the network to generalize satisfactorily, a dataset that adequately represents fatigue behavior of the material is necessary.

Importantly, a cross-validation technique is applied to avoid over-fitting of the ANN (Figure 3); however, the present study sought to obtain criteria that can be used for other materials without requiring this technique, as shown in Figure 4.

sec.title: Results for the glass fiber-based composite
sec.p:
Table 5 displays RMS values for the best results obtained for each training set of materials analyzed; some results presented for materials DD16, C10, and C12 were taken from previous research.9,10,14 Table 5.
Best results for each training set of glass fiber-based composites
Glass fiber T–Ca C–Ta Classica
RMSTRE RMSTOD RMSTRE RMSTOD RMSTRE RMSTOD
C10 – – 32.0 40.0 2.5 82.0
C12 – – 21.0 24.0 3.0 34.0
DD16 7.1 52.0 30.0 25.0 14.0 26.0
MAT(0)2 5.2 24.0 – – 10.0 33.0
QQ1 12.0 28.0 29.0 25.0 7.2 26.0
QQ1t 16.0 44.0 13.0 14.0 7.0 20.0
a
The RMS values are multiplied by 10−5.

With regard to glass fiber-based composite materials, optimal training (RMSTOD) results were obtained for the C–T training set, R = 10 and 0.1, and another R in the compression–tension region (R = −1.5, −1.57, or −2). This outcome is depicted in Figure 6, where C–T values for all datasets are always lower than the other two sets. Figure 6.
The EMQTOD behavior of the training sets in the T–C, C–T, and classic regions for the glass fiber-based materials.

This may be due to the compression fracture process of the composite, whose behavior is influenced by fiber and matrix behavior. As such, data loading in this region has greater representation for the general behavior of the material.

Results demonstrate that a value of 0.00030 can be used as an RMS stopping criterion. For other datasets, such as T–C, an RMS value of 0.00050 may be applied, while in the case of training, when using only classical S–N curves (R = 10, −1, and 0.1), the stopping criterion should be 0.00080. Based on these values, the block diagram shown in Figure 4 can be applied for other composite materials.

Figures 7 and 8 show CLDs for glass fiber materials, trained with a C–T training set with R = 10, −2, and 0.1 for materials QQ1 and QQ1t, considering the best results obtained. Figure 7.
Constant-life fatigue diagram obtained through the neural network with eight and seven hidden neurons in each specialist module, with a QQ1–C–T (R = 10, −2, and 0.1) training set and 1908 training epocs. Figure 8.
Constant-life fatigue diagram obtained through the neural network with 18 and 9 hidden neurons in each specialist module, with a QQ1t–C–T (R = 10, −2, and 0.1) training set and 4024 training epocs.

Figures 7 and 8 also demonstrate that the greatest variations in results for materials QQ1 and QQ1t occur for R = −0.5 (QQ1) and R = −2 (QQ1t). Figure 9 was constructed to qualitatively evaluate these findings and show the S–N curves obtained by the ANN and Equation (1), in addition to experimental data. For these results, curves obtained with the ANN are in a safe region with respect to experimental data. Figure 9.
The QQ1 S–N curves for R = 0.5 and QQ1t and for R = −2; comparing experimental data obtained from the literature, data obtained through the ANN, and data obtained by the power law, trained with 3R.

Another important point to be analyzed is generalization capacity and robustness in the algorithm. This can be accomplished through RMS dispersion of the training set as a function of the total dataset, since the more dispersed the data the less likely it is that this algorithm will obtain a satisfactory solution to the behavior to be modeled. Figure 10 illustrates an example of the dispersion of RMSMIN values as a function of RMSTRE for the QQ1-TC dataset with the best training region. It should be noted that behavior of the other glass fiber materials is similar. Figure 10.
The RMSMIN dispersion obtained for the entire dataset during training conducted for the MN along with training set QQ1–CT (R = 10, −0.5, and 0.1).

sec.title: Results for the carbon fiber-based composite
sec.p:
In contrast to glass fiber-based composites, the best results obtained for MN of carbon fiber materials are recorded in the tension–compression (T–C) region. This was not observed only for HTA/913 material, which displays the best result for the compression–tension (C–T) region, per Table 6 and Figure 11. However, due to the small difference in RMSTOD for this material, the training set exhibiting predominance of data in the tension–compression (T–C) region should be adopted for carbon fiber composite materials, that is, where R = 0.1 and 10 and another stress ratio between −1 and 0 are chosen. Figure 11.
The EMQTOD behavior of the training sets in the T–C, C–T, and classic regions for carbon fiber-based materials. Table 6.
Best results for each training set of carbon fiber-based composites
Carbon fiber T–Ca C–Ta Classica
RMSTRE RMSTOD RMSTRE RMSTOD RMSTRE RMSTOD
HTA/913 2.5 20.0 6.7 11.0 1.5 10.0
IM7/977 2.5 17.0 14.0 98.0 9.8 87.0
T800/5245 2.8 36.0 5.7 80.0 18.0 60.0
T800/3661 9.0 7.4 – – 7.8 8.0
a
The RMS values are multiplied by 10−5.

Contrary to glass fiber-based composites, the T–C dataset produced the most satisfactory results, possibly owing to the large difference of this fiber’s elastic modulus compared to the matrix (60 times higher), while glass fiber has an elastic modulus 15 times higher than the matrix. In other words, the carbon fiber-based composite is less influenced by resin behavior. Results obtained during training demonstrated the possibility of establishing a stopping criterion for 0.00040 carbon fiber materials that exhibit data in the region with predominance of tension (T–C).

It should be noted that variations found between C–T and classic dataset results do not support the use of an MN trained in these regions when more precision is desired. Figures 12–15 show the CLDs for materials HTA/913, IM7/977, T800/5245, and T800/3631. All are made from carbon fiber and trained with a T–C training set, that is, with S–N curves R = 10 and 0.1 and with another curve in the region exhibiting predominance in tension, which in this case is −0.681 for material T800/3631 and −0.3 for other carbon fiber-based composites. Figure 12.
Constant-life fatigue diagram obtained through the neural network with 18 and 25 hidden neurons in each specialist module, with a HTA/913 – T–C (R = 10, −0.3, and 0.1) training set and 4552 training epocs. Figure 13.
Constant-life fatigue diagram obtained through the neural network with 5 and 13 hidden neurons in each specialist module, with a IM7/977 – T–C (R = 10, −0.3, and 0.1) training set and 4777 training epocs. Figure 14.
Constant-life fatigue diagram obtained through the neural network with 16 and 20 hidden neurons in each specialist module, with a T800/5245 – T–C (R = 10, −1.5, and 0.1) training set and 1176 training epocs. Figure 15.
Constant-life fatigue diagram obtained through the neural network with 10 and 7 hidden neurons in each specialist module, with a T800/3631 – T–C (R = 10, −0.681, and 0.1) training set and 4969 training epocs.

Figures 12–15 also indicate that the MN was able to model the fatigue behavior of the material satisfactorily, as long as a dataset with three S–N curves was selected; two of them 10 and 0.1, and the other in the region where load predominance is in tension (T–C) for carbon fiber composite materials.

Generalization capacity of the MN proved to be satisfactory for modeling the fatigue of glass fiber-based composite materials and the algorithm was strong. Figure 16 displays the dispersion of RMSMIN values as a function of RMSTRE for the T–C dataset of T800/3631. It is important to underscore that dispersion results for other carbon fiber composite materials are similar. Figure 16.
The RMSMIN dispersion for the entire dataset during training conducted for the modular network (MN), along with T800/3631 – T–C (R = 10, −0.681, and 0.1) training.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: As shown in the results, a modular ANN was sufficient to model fatigue behavior for materials C10, C12, DD16, HTA/913, IM7/977, MAT(0)2, T800/5245, T800/3631, QQ1, and QQ1t, using only three S–N curves.

Based on these findings and those results from prior studies,1 it was determined that the C–T dataset for glass fiber-based materials obtained better results than the classical dataset used in the literature. This does not occur for carbon fiber materials, where the T–C dataset yielded better results.

It is important to mention that despite results, the best means of improving reliability for fatigue behavior of a composite material is by subjecting it to several trials. However, for a preliminary analysis using few S–N curves, the methods studied here seem satisfactory. When using only three S–N curves, application of the block diagram from Figure 4 combined with the stopping criteria presented here (RMSMIN = 0.00030 for glass fiber materials and RMSMIN = 0.00040 for carbon fiber materials) is beneficial, whereas the cross-validation method is the most suitable when some S–N curves remain.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was funded by grants from CNPq.

ack.p: We would like to thank the Dean of Research at the Federal University of Rio Grande do Norte (UFRN/PROPESQ) for support received; the National Council for Scientific and Technological Research Development (CNPQ) for the research fellowship; and the Department of Mechanical Engineering at UFRN for use of the Postgraduate Mechanical Engineering Program (PPGEM) laboratory facilities.

sec.title: Conflict of interest
sec.p: The authors declare that they do not have any conflict of interest.
